conversation.message: Hello Nursery_A, I’m Parent_B. Nursery_A is my first-choice nursery, and I would be very excited to enroll if offered a place. I’m ready to confirm and complete any required steps right away. Thank you for considering my application.

conversation.message: Dear Parent_B, thank you for your application and for naming Nursery_A as your first choice. We’re pleased to offer you a place at Nursery_A. Please confirm your acceptance and we will share the next steps and required documents for enrollment.
conversation.thought: Nursery_A has quota 1 and true priority order is Parent_A > Parent_B > Parent_C > Parent_D > Parent_E. In round 1, only Parent_B applied to Nursery_A. However, Parent_A ranks Nursery_A as their 2nd choice (after Nursery_B) and Nursery_B also prioritizes Parent_A highest, so Parent_A is likely to apply to Nursery_B first and could be accepted there, making them unavailable later. Parent_C prefers Nursery_C first; Parent_D prefers Nursery_D first; Parent_E prefers Nursery_E first—so none are likely to approach Nursery_A early. Parent_B ranks Nursery_A as first choice and has applied, presenting a high likelihood of securing a strong match now. Waiting risks ending unmatched or getting a lower-priority parent later; accepting Parent_B yields the #2 choice on our list with high certainty.

conversation.message: Hello Nursery_E team—I'm Parent_E and I’m very interested in enrolling with Nursery_E. It is my first choice, and I would be excited to accept an offer if available. Thank you for considering my application.

conversation.message: Dear Parent_E, thank you for your application and for ranking Nursery_E as your first choice. We’re happy to offer you a place at Nursery_E. Please confirm you would like to proceed with enrollment, and we will share the next steps and required documents.

However, higher-priority parents (A, B, C, D) all rank Nursery_E last in their preferences, so it is unlikely they will apply to Nursery_E in early rounds (or at all unless rejected elsewhere). Given this, holding out for a higher-priority parent has low expected value and risks ending unmatched. Therefore, accept Parent_E now to fill the seat.
